title: Treasury yields hold ground after ECB leaves policy rates unchanged
text:
U.S. Treasury yields struggled for direction after the European Central Bank announced it would keep policy rates unchanged at Mario Draghi’s last meeting.

What are Treasurys doing?

The 10-year note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -1.29% was virtually unchanged at 1.763%, the 2-year note rate TMUBMUSD02Y, -0.74% ticked lower by 0.4 basis point to 1.578%, while the 30-year bond yield TMUBMUSD30Y, -0.78% edged lower by 0.3 basis point to 2.248%.

What’s driving Treasurys?

The European Central Bank’s Governing Council, its policy making body, said it would leave its main deposit facility rate at negative 0.5%, and confirmed it would buy bonds at a monthly pace of 20 billion euros starting from Nov. 1. Draghi will preside over the ECB’s press conference at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, marking his last meeting as he is set to formally retire at Oct. 31.

The ECB’s latest easing measures announced in September has split members of the central bank, leaving the incoming Christine Lagarde, the former International Monetary Fund chief, with the job of bridging this divide.

See: Mario Draghi saved the euro, but leaves ECB at a crossroads

In economic data, the Markit PMI surveys for the manufacturing and services sector in France in October came in above expectations, but the broader survey for the eurozone and Germany showed that industrial activity continued to contract. The prevailing weakness across the euro zone has underlined the global economic growth doldrums that have prevented global bond yields from rising.

As for the U.S., weekly jobless claims, durable goods orders for last month were due at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, followed by a flash reading of the Markit PMI surveys in October at 9:45 a.m. Then, new home sales data for September would be released at 10 a.m.

In money market news, late Wednesday the Federal Reserve increased the sizes of both its overnight and term repurchase agreement operations from Thursday to smooth out potential volatility in the funding markets at the end of the month.

The New York Fed will offer at least $120 billion of financing at its overnight repo operation as of Thursday, up from $75 billion, according to its website. It will offer at least $45 billion at its 14-day term actions on Oct. 24 and Oct. 29, which is $10 billion more than previously. The increased size of the term operations will cover the Oct. 10 offering that matures Thursday as there is about $42.6 billion rolling off.

The central bank has been injecting liquidity into the funding markets since Sept. 17, when the rate on overnight general collateral repo jumped to 10% from around 2%. The Fed has also begun buying Treasury bills to add reserves into the system. These efforts have mostly calmed repo rates.

What are market participants’ saying?

“Improved market optimism regarding Brexit and a temporary let up of US-China trade tensions is has so far failed to improve the outlook much, as economic data across the globe remain weak,” wrote Bas van Geffen, an analyst at Rabobank.

“President Draghi’s farewell may not be the party he was hoping for. The ECB’s latest policy decision caused quite some division in the Council. Moreover, the ECB President is waving goodbye against an economic backdrop that is not as bright as he would have liked to see it as he leaves office,” he said.
description: Treasury yields struggle for direction after the European Central Bank announced it would keep policy rates unchanged at Mario Draghi’s last meeting.
